comments.commentBody:
I just read an interesting article about how a lead of 1.5 percentage points or more in state polls within 10 days of an election makes the lead statistically close to insurmountable; and, therefore, 1.5% or greater lead shouldn't be called a "toss up". You should read it: http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/10/27/oct-26-state-poll-av...

#YouMissedThePoint

Aerin-
"Webster's Dictionary" is not a copyrighted term, so there is no real such thing as "Webster's" as a source, like American Heritage. Go in a bookstore you'll find many different "Webster's Dictionaries".

Romney supporters hate big government intervention.

So let them do without FEMA, Medicare, Social Security, and the other socialist infiltration of their miserable lives.

That'll teach 'em.

Then they can go back to watching FOX and reading the bible.

Uhm...Mr. Silver did not "refuse" to evaluate those results.  He explicitly acknowledges that there is solid evidence for the incumbent rule 20-25 years ago.  His hypothesis was that in recent years, the incumbent effect has faded as polling has become more rigorous and accurate.  Given his initial hypothesis and his stated acceptance of the incumbent effect decades ago, I see no bad faith in his analysis.

Interesting that Silver refused to evaluate presidential election results over the last 60 years to test his theories on how undecided/uncommitted voters break on election day. If he did, he would find that 100% of the incumbent presidents who had average polling support below 50% in the last 3 weeks of the campaign, ended up losing.

Also, to further point out what Silver refuses to admit, analysis of all presidential elections since 1952 shows that incumbent presidents typically gain 0.4% in votes on election day over the average of their last 3 weeks of poll results, while the challenger gains an average of 2.6%. Voters break to the challenger by a substantial margin.

To further prove that challengers benefit overwhelmingly from the undecided/uncommitted vote, the average among all presidential elections shows that 4% of voters are undecided/uncommitted in the final week of polling, and the challenger gained 3% support in votes over his average last week of polling results. If a challenger gains 3 out of 4 undecided/uncommitted voters, that shows the challenger is gaining an average of 75% of the undecided/uncommitted vote in presidential campaigns.

stevedmp,
Nate's model does take turnout into account. Specifically, in the US, Republican turnout is typically stronger than Democratic. In midterm elections (2002, '06, '10…), turnout is smaller, and Republicans tend to have an advantage.
The way that Nate's model considers turnout is by comparing historical election results with the polling predictions. If a poll has a bias in favor of Republicans or Democrats, part of the reason for that is that the poll didn't calculate turnout correctly. And Nate's adjustment for "house effects" and bias corrects for that.

Republicans are generally loud, condescending, and mean--you can not count on them to give an accurate description of anything and they are best ignored.  Be glad you don't have these tools in your country.

Indeed. Why don't we have a long weekend of voting. Why don't we tie the vote securely to the SSN and be done with all that nonsense about voter fraud. Why don't we hand-count paper ballots in bi-partisan groups, as elsewhere in the world. Why is the US the only Western country where election results are habitually fishy.

Answer: the current system helps Republicans, and only a supermajority could change it. Heartbreaking.

Nate Silver, I love you.  In these days of reported tightening of the polls, of Obama´s advantage among women voters vanissing, and of Republican bravado etc, visiting the 538 site is like taking refuge and finding comfort and reassurance (and I´m  not Amercian or even living in the US.).  It´s essential reading. Ok, most of us on here seem to be pro Obama and therefore like what we read, but the analysis seems so thorough.  Just one question, how have you  factored in the turn-out rate and how could this affect the result?  Is there a historical difference between the two parties´supporters turn-out rates? In he UK for example there´s an arguement (perhaps it´s true, perhaps not) that the Conservative voters are more likely to turn out then Labour supporters.  There´s been some discussion above about how Sandy would have a different impact on Rep. and Democrats with the lower income voters logically less likely to vote in advserse weather.  With that in mind, why is the US election always in November?  Probably not an issue in the southern states but even so for the northern states there must be better times of the year to campaign and get out the vote?  No British prime minister would chose to "go to the country" at this time of the year (eg Gordon Brown´s last minute pull-out a few years ago, albeit for other reasons apart from having an election campaign after the clocks had gone back.)

Gallup has Obama leading in every region of this country except one, the south. When it showed Romeny with a 7 point lead, it had him loosing in the east, midwest, and west, but winning by 22 points in the south!
This is why we pay close attention to state polls.

I can't help but wonder how Gallup and Rasmussen national numbers can add up when just about every single heavily populated state, outside of TX, is for Obama by high single digits or more.  FL is even, but IL, NY, MA, NJ, PA, MI, CA are firmly in the Obama column and he holds a clear lead electoraly.  It seems improbable to have someone polling in states that will give them a clear electoral majority but behind in the popular vote.  I suspect the national polls giving Romney a five or seven point lead need to check their sampling methodology.
I'm hoping that it will effect rather than affect voter turnout.

I'm scared of that hurricane Sandy hurting the people in the States that is likely to be affected by it.

Say a prayer for our Great Country, now!

And also pray that this storm will not effect voter turnout in many States.

Hi Nate,
Don't know if you ever read these comments, but I bought your lovely book! The first 5 pages about the rise of the printing press were a slog, but after that the pace really picks up and it's wonderful. Love your impartial number-crunching analyses.
Yes, let's blame what PACs do on the candidate they back. If you don't like it, blame the Supreme Court hacks your party installed.
Your point is...?
Putin? Please don't bring those dusty old talking points around here. Putin has nothing to do with our election.

Final point. Campaigns that are really confident don't take risks like that virginity ad that Obama ripped off from Putin. Whatever you thought of it, and I thought it inane and undignified, it was a dice roll.
If Democrats don't vote because of the weather, maybe they shouldn't be voting at all.
Thank you, Coffeybrook. I'm bemused by those who've been thinking that this storm will shut down Eastern cities for a week afterwards. It's extraordinarily unlikely.

Good Lord,Pragmatist, you're still at it!

1) How much are you paid per posting?

2) Your lack of respect for voters who don't share your point of view is apparent, and you've disparaged "low-information" voters as well; how do you feel about low-information Tea-publicans ("keep you're government hands off my Medicare")?

3) If it turns out that President Obama is successful in his bid for reelection, will you either acknowledge your logical errors or just quietly disappear?

We may be watching the Weather Channel instead of the polls if Philadelphia gets power outages and floods.

Philadelphia is very heavily democratic and it holds about 1.5 million votes. That's slightly more than 1/10 of PA's votes.

If Democrats don't vote because of the weather, we'll need Colorado to offset PA...
Well, that's all fine, but both polls on their own, tell us very little in terms of electorate and swing states.  this is what everyone keeps missing in this picture.
The point is ....who cares about these polls. We are mostly concerned with state polling as the electoral college determines the election.
Enjoy your cherries.

Note also that Obama's approval ratings in both Gallup and Rasmussen have tanked in the last week and are now around the 47 number. Before you claim that these polls are biased, they both had Obama at well over 50 earlier in the month.
Console yourself, Mr. Mullen. There is a track record here.
Mr. Silver, love your charts, comments, etc., but perhaps I'm influenced by seeing that my guy stands to win. I hope you are as objective and thorough as is humanly possible.
mmm... National Review, that bastion of objectivity.

Is this the same Gallup brand which is owned by a consulting firm that makes all its money from big businesses?

You don't think they could have a right wing bias do you?
"The party-affiliation polls from Gallup and Rasmussen." That says it all, no need to read futher.

For all those who think Nate Silver has an accurate model, and that Obama is going to sweep this election (as Nate's model predicts a 71% chance of victory), you might want to read this article in the National Review: http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/331828/two-polls-have-chicago-terri...

This is why Obama and his entire team are panicking. You don't see Nate Silver talking about the Gallup demographic breakdown because it blows a hole right in the middle of Nate's entire theory, and it's too late in the game for Nate to adjust his model to account for the major shift in the demographic compared with 2008. Every Obama fan needs to read the article I just cited, because it will open your eyes to the cold, harsh reality of this election.
As a new Ohio transplant, I am loving that my vote counts this year! Previously, I've voted in NYC and Oklahoma -- not swinging anything in either of those states.
awesome

I take great comfort in the sciences, myself pursuing evolutionary biology. In the sciences, among your peers, you are only as good as your hypotheses. If it becomes known that you are basing your hypotheses on emotional thought rather than rational, clinical thought, you become irrelevant. What you see with Nate, and nerds like him, is a lack of a "bedside manner" that many complain makes a person too "clinical". In the world of political statistics, Nate and his colleagues are subject to very emotionally driven responses from people, and must maintain that clinical approach, which might make them seem like erudite snobs, but when it comes to this stuff, it's what you want to see. I find sanity in the cool steadiness of numbers wonks. It could be the end of the world, and they'll merely peer a bit more closely through their inevitable glasses and comment, "Hmm, let me more accurately figure out which sentient life forms will suffer the most and for how long, etc etc". I think it's safe to say, no matter how many of you uh, "trolls" try to verbally eviscerate Nate, (which most of you laughably suck at), he most probably doesn't care. He will continue to put forth inexorable numbers that do not care what you feel on any given day. Because facts are meant to be just that: facts, free from personal ideology. Carry on....

It's the electoral college that matters. State polls are higher quality polls with bigger samples.

People keep chipring over and over again about national polls. And they love mentioning Gallup in this argument. When in reality Gallup has been an outlier this year.

Can't wait until November 6th so all of these Amateur pollsters (you included) can stop trying to act like they know anything.

Ethan, thanks for you input. I believe that you saying that many of the states "at play" have similar voting tenancies (i.e. aren't orthogonal to one another); is that correct?

If possible, please point me to and article or place where this discussion occurred. I'm quite interested.

Well, Silver didn't exactly shine in 2010 either. And both were dead on in 2008.
So you don't like Rasmussen. How about Gallup? Battleground? AP? ABC News?

The national polls aren't good for Obama, period. An incumbent sitting at 47 (on average) and trailing his opponent is weak. It isn't just Rasmussen (who actually has a pretty small 'house effect' according to Silver).

But feel free to indulge in the fantasy of an electoral vote - popular vote split.

And...Romney is running from the press... and restrategizing to win Wisconsin.  Rob Portman, Romney's surrogate said that it would be much harder for them to win without Ohio...and early voting in Ohio leans Dem.  Obama is working like a man who wants to keep his job.  What's wrong with that.  He's giving interviews and letting people know what he'll do in the next 4 years.  Romney is running from the press telling people to "Trust Him" without specifics.
Don't forget Pete Kent from 2008, the original "This is Great News for John McCain" guy.

If Nate keeps including polls like the latest WASHPOST poll, which has a sample of +8 Dem in Virginia and, not surprisingly, shows a lead of 4 points for Obama, Virginia will continue to be light blue on his map. This is patently absurd. Multiply this poll by several dozen and you can see why CO and OH remain light blue according to Nate. Garbage in, garbage out.

I'm betting it's Gallup. Nate refuses to see the dam breaking all around his hypothesis. Today the Des Monies Register endorsed Romney. Their first endorsement for a Republican since 1972. "when the walls come crumblin down"...toast!

Eric Tarini, the bailout is already reflected in the polls (as is Obama's "war on coal"), so if the numbers are unstable, it's irrelevant, the numbers are just unstable.  Btw, by your theory Romney should be getting 0% in Ohio.

Well"prgamatist" if you were no so lazy or inept you could read all about how the model was developed way back years ago and adjusted in the spring.

Start here http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/22/calculating-house-ef...

The RATINGS of the pollsters was determined way even before Obama ran in 2008 and has been adjusted according to their results and accuracy since.

Your over-the-top paranoia is showing.

Tim, I wish your article distinguished between political leanings; because of related, but more controversial, research about differences among conservatives and progressives in justifying their beliefs. http://www.alternet.org/right-wing-psyche-allergic-reality-new-study-sho...

Related: Recent studies show differences between the brains of conservatives and progressives.Here's wiki as a jumping-off point: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biology_and_political_orientation
